Crime_Name: Administrative Failure under the Income Tax Act
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister of National Revenue breached the duty to assess the tax return with all due dispatch
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed the delay was motivated by a policy to deter participation in GLGI, not to verify claims
Decision_Outcome: Court declared the Minister failed to assess with all due dispatch
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to demonstrate failure in statutory duty
Credibility_Factor: CRA's stated purpose versus actual intent in delaying assessments
Legal_Rule: Section 152(1) requires assessment 'with all due dispatch', interpreted as within a reasonable time
Procedural_Issue: Delay in assessment due to local CRA policy
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper motive behind delay; policy inconsistent with national direction and statutory duty
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and administrative law reasonableness
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Assessment delayed for improper purpose, violating fair administration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence and implementation of Winnipeg Tax Centre’s delay policy targeting GLGI participants
Applicant_Challenge: Minister’s failure to comply with statutory duty under s. 152(1)
Defendant_Response: Implied justification based on compliance verification, but found pretextual
Remedy_Requested: Declaration regarding failure to meet statutory obligation
Outcome: Declaration issued in favor of Applicant
Decision_Authority: Federal Court or applicable tax court
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 152(1) of the Income Tax Act
Governing_Rule: Section 152(1), Income Tax Act – duty to assess with all due dispatch
